title: 108_s2292
content: The Act titled "Global Anti-Semitism Review Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. The findings section follows. Congress finds that acts of anti-Semitism have increased significantly worldwide in recent years, with specific incidents cited in Malaysia and Turkey. In various countries, acts of anti-Semitism have been on the rise, including car bombings at synagogues, poisoning of lawns with anti-Semitic slogans, desecration of gravestones with swastikas, and vandalism of Jewish schools and cemeteries with anti-Semitic graffiti. In Toulon, France, a Jewish synagogue and community center were set on fire in 2004. Anti-Semitism is increasing from the Arab and Muslim world through government-owned publishing houses and TV series promoting conspiracy theories against Jews. The rise in anti-Semitic violence has led to international organizations like the OSCE holding conferences to address the issue. The United States government has supported efforts to combat anti-Semitism through relationships with organizations such as the OSCE, the European Union, and the United Nations. Congress has also consistently backed initiatives to tackle anti-Semitism. During the 107th Congress, resolutions were passed expressing concern over the sharp rise in anti-Semitic violence in Europe. Congress has consistently supported efforts to address anti-Semitism, including vilification of Zionism and incitement against Israel. Congress supports combating anti-Semitism globally through bilateral relationships and engagement with international organizations like the OSCE, EU, and UN. The Department of State should document anti-Semitic acts worldwide. The Secretary of State must submit a one-time report on acts of anti-Semitism globally, including violence against Jewish people and community institutions, government responses, laws protecting religious freedom, anti-bias education efforts, and instances of propaganda. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE TO MONITOR AND COMBAT ANTI-SEMITISM. The State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 is amended to include a new section for monitoring and combating anti-Semitism globally. SEC. 59. MONITORING AND COMBATING ANTI-SEMITISM. The Secretary of State shall establish an Office to Monitor and Combat anti-Semitism, with the head of the Office being the Special Envoy for Monitoring and Combating anti-Semitism appointed by the Secretary. The Special Envoy may be chosen from Department officers and employees. The Office to Monitor and Combat anti-Semitism, headed by the Special Envoy, is responsible for monitoring and combating acts of anti-Semitism in foreign countries, coordinating the preparation of reports on anti-Semitism for inclusion in annual human rights reports, and assisting in assessing the nature and extent of anti-Semitic incitement. The Special Envoy is responsible for coordinating the preparation of reports on anti-Semitism for inclusion in annual human rights reports and consulting with relevant organizations. Additionally, information concerning acts of anti-Semitism in foreign countries will be included in the Department of State's annual reports. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new paragraph requiring a description of acts of anti-Semitism and incitement in annual reports. This includes physical violence, harassment, vandalism of Jewish institutions, propaganda promoting racial hatred, and inciting violence against Jewish people. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new paragraph requiring a description of acts of anti-Semitism and incitement in annual reports, including physical violence, harassment, vandalism of Jewish institutions, propaganda promoting racial hatred, and inciting violence against Jewish people. The amendment also calls for details on government responses to such violence, efforts to protect religious freedom, and promotion of anti-bias education. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to include a new clause requiring an assessment of acts of anti-Semitism and anti-Semitic incitement in annual reports. This includes details on the nature and extent of such acts in the preceding year. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to include a new clause mandating an assessment of acts of anti-Semitism and incitement in annual reports. This involves documenting acts of violence, harassment, vandalism, and propaganda targeting Jewish people and institutions, as well as government responses and efforts to promote religious freedom and tolerance education. The effective date of the amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) shall apply to reports under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 submitted more than 180 days after the enactment of this Act.
